p: When programmer make use of a given function in different programs, rather than redefining it in each program they write, they put them in special programs called libraries and they have a way to ensure that their other programs can use the functions that are found in the library.

You are going to use the function turn_right() a lot! Instead of rewriting it each time (remember Rule # 3), what you are going to do is to write it once (more) but, this time, instead of writing it in the editor with the Code tab, you will click on the Library tab and write it there. Oh, and you should also write turn_around() there as well. Once you have done this, you need to do two things.

ol.li: Click on save so that it will be available for you anytime you come back to Reeborg's world. (I don't expect you to go through all the lessons in one single visit.)

Go back to the Code editor (so you no longer see your turn_right() and turn_around() functions) and write a short program that nonetheless uses them to make sure that they work as expected. If they don't, go back and fix them ... and save the version that works properly by clicking on save again.

p: From now on, whenever you define a function that you use more than once, add it to your library so that you don't have to redefine it every time.
We've mentioned it before but it bears repeating in case you did not read it the first time.

In addition to the Library tab, you may have noticed the Notes tab. If you click on that tab, you will not see an editor, like the other two, but a rectangular "box" where you can put in any text you want and save it. It's a great place to save individual programs. There should be at least one hundred if not a thousand times more space provided by your browser than what would be required to save all the solutions (programs), including comments (so that you would know what program solves what problem) for all the suggested exercises and challenges that you will find on this website. Don't be shy, use it!
